Avogadro’s constant. The number of particles (atoms, molecules or ions) present in one mole of any substance is ﬁx ed, with a value of 6.022 × 1023. This number is called the Avogadro Constant or Avogadro Number, named in honour of the Italian scientist, Amedeo Avogadro. Planck's constant - It is the physical constant that relates the energy carried by a single photon to its corresponding frequency. Faraday’s constant - It is deﬁ ned as the magnitude of the electric charge carried by one mole of electrons.

Plumpuddingmodel. According to this model, the atom was thought to consist of a positively charged sphere with negatively charged electrons embedded in it, similar to plums in a pudding. This model was later replaced by Rutherford's nuclear model of the atom. The gold foil model was proposed by Ernest Rutherford in 1911. The double-slit experiment conducted by Thomas Young in 1801. The oil dropexperiment was performed by Robert A. Millikan and Harvey Fletcher in 1909.

CsOH>KOH>NaOH>LiOH. This order is due to the increasing size of the alkali metal ions, which leads to better solvation and greater basicity. The process of dissolving an acid or a base in water is a highly exothermic one. Care must be taken while mixing concentrated nitric acid or sulphuric acid with water. The acid must always be added slowly to water with constant stirring. Mixing an acid or base with water results in a decrease in the concentration of ions (H 3O+/OH–) per unit volume. Such a process is called dilution and the acid or the base is said to be diluted.

13and19. Structure of Butane (C4H10): It has 4 carbon atoms arranged in a chain, each bonded with single covalent bonds. Each carbon atom is also bonded to hydrogen atoms to satisfy the valency of 4. Covalent bonds in Butane: Carbon-carbon single bonds = 3. Carbon-hydrogen bonds = 10. Total = 3 + 10 = 13 covalent bonds. Structure of Hexane (C6H14): It has 6 carbon atoms in a straight chain, each bonded with single covalent bonds, and bonded to hydrogen atoms to satisfy the valency of 4. Covalent bonds in Hexane: Carbon-carbon single bonds = 5. Carbon-hydrogen bonds = 14. Total = 5 + 14 = 19 covalent bonds.

Halogens, located in Group 17, are situated toward the right of their period, giving them smaller atomic sizes compared to elements on the left. They are reactive non-metals that form diatomic molecules (e.g., Cl2, F2) and are found to the left of the noble gases in the periodic table. The largest atomic size in a period is typically observed in the alkali metals (Group 1), not in the halogens.

Atomic radius. Ionization energy is the energy needed to remove an electron from an atom. As the atomic radius increases, the outer electrons are farther from the nucleus, reducing the attraction between them and the nucleus. This makes it easier to remove an electron, resulting in lower ionization energy. Electronegativity is the ability of an atom to attract shared electrons. Atomic mass is the sum of protons and neutrons, with minor contributions from electrons. Electron a ﬃ nity measures the attraction between an incoming electron and the nucleus, with stronger attraction releasing more energy.

P. Newland's Law of Octaves states that when chemical elements are arranged in order of increasing atomic weight, elements with similar properties occur every eight elements. Nitrogen (N) is in the 7th position in the periodic table. To ﬁnd the element with similar properties, we need to add 8 to 7, which gives us 15. The element in the 15th position is Phosphorus (P).

FrequencyofX-raysemitted. Henry Moseley's 1913 experiment involved studying the X-ray spectra of various elements and led to the discovery of atomic numbers. He observed that the frequency (ν) of the X-rays emitted by an element was directly proportional to the square of its atomic number Z.

sodium. In 1865, the English chemist J.A.R. Newlands proposed the Law of Octaves. It states that when chemical elements are arranged by increasing atomic mass, elements with similar physical and chemical properties appear after every interval of seven. Examples include Lithium (Li) and Sodium (Na), as well as Beryllium (Be) and Magnesium (Mg). Limitations : Only applicable up to calcium, assumed only 56 elements existed in nature, and became irrelevant after the discovery of the Noble gases.

d. The periodic table is an arrangement of chemical elements into rows ("periods") and columns ("groups"), showcasing periodic trends in their properties. Electronegativity is a chemical property that measures an atom's ability to attract shared electrons in a molecule. The electronegativity of an atom is in ﬂ uenced by its atomic number and the distance of its valence electrons from the positively charged nucleus.

JohannWolfgangDobereiner developed the concept of Dobereiner's Triads in 1817. He observed that certain groups of three elements (triads) had similar chemical properties, and the atomic mass of the middle element was roughly the average of the other two. This was an early attempt to classify elements based on their properties.

Germanium (Ge) is a metalloid in the carbon group (Group 14) of the periodic table, and it is chemically similar to its group neighbors tin (Sn) and silicon (Si). This similarity arises because all three elements share similar electron conﬁ gurations and chemical properties, such as forming covalent bonds and having semiconductor characteristics.

C. To determine the course of a reaction and make qualitative predictions about how changes in conditions affect equilibrium, we use Le Chatelier’s principle. This principle states that a change in any of the factors that determine the equilibrium conditions of a system will cause the system to change in such a manner so as to reduce or to counteract the effect of the change. This is applicable to all physical and chemical equilibria.

The reaction between sodium chloride (NaCl), water (H2O), carbon dioxide (CO2), and ammonia (NH3) produces sodium bicarbonate (baking soda) as part of the Solvay process.The chemical equation for this reaction is: NaCl+H2O+CO2+NH,→NaHCO3+NH4Cl Here, NaHCO 3is baking soda, and NH 4Cl (ammonium chloride) is a by-product.

Decomposition of calcium carbonate. A redox reaction is de ﬁ ned as a reaction in which oxidation and reduction take place simultaneously.
